ai-sn5:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn5:1.1.3_0: Then the nun Āḷavikā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-sn5:1.1.4_0: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest seeking seclusion.
ai-sn5:1.1.5_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Āḷavī feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from seclusion and went up to her.
ai-sn5:1.1.5_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Āḷavikā with a verse:
ai-sn5:1.2.2_0: Why then do you seek seclusion?
ai-sn5:1.2.3_0: Enjoy the delights of sensual pleasure;
ai-sn5:1.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:1.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from seclusion!”
ai-sn5:1.3.5_0: Then Māra the Wicked, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:1.4.1_0: “There is an escape in the world,
ai-sn5:1.4.2_0: and I’ve personally experienced it with wisdom.
ai-sn5:1.4.3_0: O Wicked One, kinsman of the negligent,
ai-sn5:1.5.1_0: Sensual pleasures are like swords and stakes;
ai-sn5:1.5.2_0: the aggregates are their chopping block.
ai-sn5:1.5.4_0: has become no delight for me.”
ai-sn5:1.6.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Āḷavikā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:2.1.2_0: Then the nun Somā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-sn5:2.1.3_0: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest,
ai-sn5:2.1.4_0: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-sn5:2.1.5_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Somā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and went up to her.
ai-sn5:2.1.5_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Somā with a verse:
ai-sn5:2.2.2_0: it’s for the sages to attain.
ai-sn5:2.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:2.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:2.3.5_0: Then Somā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:2.4.4_0: as they rightly discern the Dhamma.”
ai-sn5:2.6.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Somā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:3.1.2_0: Then the nun Kisāgotamī robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-sn5:3.1.3_0: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest,
ai-sn5:3.1.4_0: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-sn5:3.1.5_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Kisāgotamī feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and went up to her.
ai-sn5:3.1.5_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Kisāgotamī with a verse:
ai-sn5:3.2.1_0: “Why do you, like one with a dead son,
ai-sn5:3.2.3_0: You’ve come to the woods all alone—
ai-sn5:3.2.4_0: you must be looking for a man!”
ai-sn5:3.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:3.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:3.4.1_0: Then Kisāgotamī, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:3.5.4_0: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!
ai-sn5:3.6.2_0: and the mass of darkness is shattered.
ai-sn5:3.6.3_0: He defeated the army of death,
ai-sn5:3.7.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Kisāgotamī knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:4.1.2_0: Then the nun Vijayā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:4.1.3_0: he sat down to dwell for the day at the root of a certain tree.
ai-sn5:4.1.4_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Vijayā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and went up to her.
ai-sn5:4.1.4_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Vijayā with a verse:
ai-sn5:4.2.2_0: and I’m a youth in my prime.
ai-sn5:4.2.3_0: Come, my lady, let us enjoy
ai-sn5:4.2.4_0: the music of a five-piece band.”
ai-sn5:4.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:4.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:4.3.5_0: Then Vijayā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:4.4.4_0: for I have no use for them.
ai-sn5:4.5.3_0: I’m horrified and repelled by it,
ai-sn5:4.5.4_0: craving for sensual pleasures is eradicated.
ai-sn5:4.6.1_0: There are beings in the realm of luminous form,
ai-sn5:4.6.2_0: and others established in the formless.
ai-sn5:4.6.4_0: I’ve destroyed the darkness regarding all of them.”
ai-sn5:4.7.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vijayā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:5.1.2_0: Then the nun Uppalavaṇṇā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:5.1.3_0: she stood at the root of a Sāla tree in full flower.
ai-sn5:5.1.4_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Uppalavaṇṇā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and from her.
ai-sn5:5.1.4_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Uppalavaṇṇā with a verse:
ai-sn5:5.2.1_0: “You’ve come to this sal tree all crowned with flowers,
ai-sn5:5.2.2_0: You stay alone at the root of the Sāla tree,
ai-sn5:5.2.3_0: Your beauty is second to none;
ai-sn5:5.2.4_0: silly girl, aren’t you afraid of rascals?”
ai-sn5:5.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:5.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:5.3.5_0: Then Uppalavaṇṇā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:5.4.3_0: Not a body-hair would shake or tremble,
ai-sn5:5.4.4_0: I’m not scared of you, Māra, even alone.
ai-sn5:5.5.3_0: I could stand between your eyebrows
ai-sn5:5.5.4_0: and you still wouldn’t see me.
ai-sn5:5.6.1_0: I’m the master of my own mind,
ai-sn5:5.6.2_0: I’ve developed the bases of psychic power well.
ai-sn5:5.6.4_0: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!”
ai-sn5:5.7.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Uppalavaṇṇā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:6.1.2_0: Then the nun Cālā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:6.1.3_0: he sat down to dwell for the day at the root of a certain tree.
ai-sn5:6.1.4_0: Then Māra the Wicked went up to Cālā and said to her,
ai-sn5:6.2.3_0: Who put this idea in your head:
ai-sn5:6.3.1_0: “Death comes to those who are born,
ai-sn5:6.3.2_0: when you’re born you undergo sufferings—
ai-sn5:6.3.4_0: That’s why you shouldn’t approve of rebirth.
ai-sn5:6.4.1_0: The Buddha taught me the Dhamma
ai-sn5:6.4.3_0: teaches the Dhamma so that living creatures
ai-sn5:6.4.4_0: he settled me in the truth.
ai-sn5:6.5.1_0: There are beings in the realm of luminous form,
ai-sn5:6.5.2_0: and others established in the formless.
ai-sn5:6.6.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Cālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:7.1.2_0: Then the nun Upacālā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:7.1.3_0: he sat down to dwell for the day at the root of a certain tree.
ai-sn5:7.1.4_0: Then the Wicked Māra approached the nun Upacālā,
ai-sn5:7.1.4_1: and after approaching he said this to the nun Upacālā:
ai-sn5:7.1.5_0: “Where would you like to be reborn?”
ai-sn5:7.1.6_0: “I don’t want to be reborn anywhere, sir.”
ai-sn5:7.2.1_0: “The Gods of the Thirty-Three, and those of Yama;
ai-sn5:7.2.4_0: and the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others—
ai-sn5:7.3.1_0: “The Gods of the Thirty-Three, and those of Yama;
ai-sn5:7.3.4_0: and the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others—
ai-sn5:7.3.5_0: they’re bound with the bonds of sensuality;
ai-sn5:7.3.6_0: they fall under your sway again.
ai-sn5:7.5.4_0: and not frequented by ordinary people.”
ai-sn5:7.6.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Upacālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:8.1.2_0: Then the nun Sīsupacālā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:8.1.3_0: he sat down to dwell for the day at the root of a certain tree.
ai-sn5:8.1.4_0: Then the Wicked Māra approached the nun Sīsupacālā,
ai-sn5:8.1.4_1: and after approaching he said this to the nun Sīsupacālā:
ai-sn5:8.1.5_0: “Nun, whose creed do you believe in?”
ai-sn5:8.2.1_0: “In whose name did you shave your head?
ai-sn5:8.2.3_0: but you don’t believe in any creed.
ai-sn5:8.2.4_0: Why do you live as if lost?”
ai-sn5:8.3.2_0: and are seen in the next.
ai-sn5:8.4.1_0: But there is one born in the Sakyan clan,
ai-sn5:8.5.3_0: I’ve attained the ending of all deeds.
ai-sn5:8.5.4_0: freed with the ending of attachments.
ai-sn5:8.5.5_0: That Blessed One is my Teacher,
ai-sn5:8.5.6_0: and I believe in his instruction.”
ai-sn5:8.6.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Sīsupacālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:9.1.2_0: Then the nun Selā robed up in the morning ...
ai-sn5:9.1.3_0: he sat down to dwell for the day at the root of a certain tree.
ai-sn5:9.1.4_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Selā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps ...
ai-sn5:9.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:9.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:9.3.5_0: Then Selā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:9.4.2_0: nor is this misery made by another.
ai-sn5:9.4.3_0: It comes to be be because of a cause,
ai-sn5:9.4.4_0: and ceases when the cause breaks up.
ai-sn5:9.5.1_0: It’s like a seed that’s sown
ai-sn5:9.5.4_0: both of them and of them.
ai-sn5:9.6.1_0: In the same way the aggregates and elements
ai-sn5:9.6.3_0: come to be be because of a cause,
ai-sn5:9.6.4_0: and cease when the cause breaks up.”
ai-sn5:9.7.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Selā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:10.1.2_0: Then the nun Vajirā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-sn5:10.1.3_0: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Dark Forest,
ai-sn5:10.1.4_0: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-sn5:10.1.5_0: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Vajirā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and went up to her.
ai-sn5:10.1.5_1: and after approaching he addressed the nun Vajirā with a verse:
ai-sn5:10.3.2_0: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
ai-sn5:10.3.4_0: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
ai-sn5:10.3.5_0: Then Vajirā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
ai-sn5:10.4.3_0: This is just a pile of conditions,
ai-sn5:10.4.4_0: Here a being tormented with beings
ai-sn5:10.5.3_0: So too, when the aggregates are present
ai-sn5:10.5.4_0: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.
ai-sn5:10.6.1_0: But it’s only suffering that comes to be,
ai-sn5:10.6.3_0: Naught but suffering comes to be,
ai-sn5:10.7.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vajirā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
ai-sn5:10.7.2_0: The first nun sub-chapter on lying down is finished.
ai-sn5:10.8.6_0: The Linked Discourses with nuns are complete.
